content: hi time for us to explore a new
environment let's make a new set of tiles these are steampunk tiles draw
inspiration from the Dwemer ruins in the game Skyrim as always we start with the
tile foundations using double corrugated cardboard here which is sturdy and
conveniently a quarter of an inch thick so we're going to cut two and a half
inch squares optionally apply corrugation cladding this is just very
thin cardstock or even plain old printer paper will work just rip strips a
quarter of an inch wide and hot glue them on for the walls we need chipboard
this is the stuff you see at the back of a notepad I use graphics medium
chipboard which is very sturdy very cheap and a sixteenth of an inch thick
cut some strips that are a half inch wide and two and a half inches long
we'll also use some foam board with the paper peeled off of both sides I got
this from Dollar Tree one of the classic DM Scotty finds but
if you'll get the more expensive stuff the paper won't peel as easily try some
rubbing alcohol to loosen it before peeling foam board is about 3/16 of an
inch thick which when attached to chipboard gives us the proper quarter
inch thick wall if you're new to the channel check out episode 1 for further
explanation so for the walls the idea is that we glue on some chunks of foam as
well as some other gears and bits I put some links in the video description
below when attaching these small metal bits and beads it might be wiser to use
superglue than hot glue so that you have finer control and less glue squishing
out so here's two examples also a drinking straw there notice there's a
gap without any feature after all the painting is done later I'll be attaching
a gemstone there so plan ahead as for the game spaces mix it up there
as well here's some cross stitching mesh sometimes referred to as granny greeting
available at any craft store just cut a one and a quarter inch square and attach
it here's one of the larger gears and a lot I'm just gonna straight up use that
as a space and we'll also use some chipboard again a one and a quarter inch
square and I like to just snip off each corner attach a wall with hot glue
use a very thin bead for any length that doesn't have foam to grab on to these
end up being sturdier than you might think
here they are pre painting I'm just gonna take a moment and pan around so
you can get some ideas and see how I randomized it I basically raided my
stray bits box looking for stuff anything you put on the wall should
result in an overall thickness of a quarter-inch and as it turns out most
beads will do exactly that it's okay to be less thick than that but too thick
means that our clip-on features won't work
paint them black first do the stone parts use a dark grey and then a light
gray stipple them on with a brush or a bit of kitchen sponge
then use metallics to hit all the bits just use whatever's in your collection
pick a silver ish color and a copper ish color and try to get both tones
appearing on each tile alright let's go check out the finished product you might
remember this metal door from episode 31 goes pretty well with these tiles if I
had one thing to do over it would obviously be the paint job I wish I had
applied that grey stone speckle to the floors before attaching any game spaces
right now it's just black in between um and underneath them and as a result any
stray painting mistakes clearly show up on the plus side it does give a nice
sense of shadow to the room and really helps those gears pop but anyway your
mileage may vary for all you 3d printers out there don't forget to check out
Hiro's hoard where you can get true tiles models as well as a ton of other
excellent fantasy related scenery hi my Locke thank you for joining me and I'll
see you next time
you
